awd_titl_txt: Hyperpolarized Multi-Spin Systems as Qubits for Quantum Information Science
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael R. Wasielewski of the Department of Chemistry at Northwestern University is developing a fundamental understanding of how to control charge and spin transport through organic molecules.  Such control is critical to the future of electronics, computers, and quantum information science (QIS). The degree of control over molecular structure and properties afforded by this research makes it possible to develop molecules and materials that take advantage of electron spin changes to implement new strategies for computer of the future that may have speeds and encryption technologies far beyond the current models. The Wasielewski research group volunteers in the Science In The Classroom program (SITC), with 3rd/4th-graders at an elementary school in an historically under-served and diverse community in Chicago. Approximately one third of the classes served by SITC are multilingual, and learn English as a second language alongside the regular curriculum. By volunteering with the same class of students for the academic year, Northwestern students mentor and inspire young scientists. The research team also participates in the program "Letters to a Pre-Scientist" which focuses on creating personal connections between middle school students from underprivileged schools and scientists to encourage the younger students to consider science as a career by writing letters as a pen pals. 

Photogenerated molecular excited states and electron transfer reactions are playing an increasing role in quantum information science (QIS). This project will address several goals based on what are known in the QIS field as the DiVincenzo criteria, which are essential for exploiting multi-radical assemblies as spin qubits that target QIS applications. Professor Wasielewski and his group use two spin-selective photophysical processes to hyperpolarize electron spins to generate well-defined initial quantum states of spin qubits and determine the dephasing mechanisms of the spin qubits.  The team then manipulates and addresses specific spin qubits to demonstrate quantum gates and uses both microwave and visible photon pulses to move (teleport) spin coherences between two sites.  Finally, the team establishes strategies for scalable spin qubit arrays based on DNA hairpin structures. They use laser excitation to generate the initial hyperpolarized spin qubits and time-resolved pulse electron paramagnetic resonance (pulse-EPR) spectroscopy to observe, manipulate and control the coherent spin states of these qubits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Photogenerated molecular multi-spin systems offer a variety of benefits compared to other materials for quantum information science (QIS) applications, such as structural reproducibility, atomic scale spatial control, structural modularity, and access to other molecular degrees of freedom. Molecular architectures provide unmatched flexibility for tailoring quantum properties using bottom-up synthetic strategies. It is well known that electron spins are good quantum bits (qubits) because their two spin states constitute the quintessential two-level quantum system, in which the two states can exist in a superposition. In addition, coupling two or more spins via the spin-spin exchange and/or dipolar interactions results in rich spin physics that allows for quantum entanglement as well as implementation of two-qubit gates essential for quantum computing. As with all such systems, the primary challenge is generating specific well-defined initial quantum states of the system that maintain their spin coherence for times long enough to permit a useful number of spin manipulations to conduct quantum gate operations. These requirements are two of the so-called DiVincenzo criteria that define what constitutes a good qubit. These criteria are difficult to fulfill using the Boltzmann populations of the electron spin states because the energy gap between the states is so small. For example, achieving > 95% spin polarization requires millikelvin temperatures. In addition, if one uses the Zeeman interaction to increase the energy gap, even temperatures on the order of 4 K still require magnetic field strengths of about 10 T.

This project demonstrated several key DiVincenzo criteria at temperatures of 85K that are essential for exploiting molecular multi-spin assemblies as spin qubits. We have 1) demonstrated two spin-selective light-driven processes that can hyperpolarize electron spins to generate well-defined initial quantum states of spin qubits; 2) determined the decoherence mechanisms of these spin qubits; 3) manipulated and addressed specific molecular spin qubits to demonstrate quantum gates; 4) used both microwave and visible photon pulses to move (teleport) spin coherences between two sites; and 5) established strategies for scalable spin qubit arrays based on DNA hairpin structures.

The students who engaged in this project were taught to prepare complex molecules and materials, while at the same time learning the physical techniques necessary to answer the questions addressed in their research. Moreover, they were strongly encouraged to develop an understanding and practical skills in whatever technique is necessary to solve their research problems. In this project, we also actively recruited and mentored women scientists. This has been one of our long-term, ongoing goals. Women scientists from our research group co-founded and remain very active in the organization Women in Science and Engineering Research (WISER) that seeks to support women in STEM fields as they advance through graduate school and pursue fulfilling professional careers. In addition, we participate in STEM education programs to develop and execute novel, impactful science programs in K-12 education including teacher professional development. Our outreach efforts in the K-12 teacher-training program and after-school program promote broad advocacy for scientific research to solve real-world problems and attract the widest talent base. This program continues to be a major means through which we disseminate our research broadly, while promoting teaching, training, and learning.
